receipt.mainchain.addr.merge_dataflows: function _submitWithdrawal(Transfer.Receipt calldata receipt, Signature[] memory signatures) internal virtual returns (bool locked) {    uint256 id = receipt.id;    uint256 quantity = receipt.info.quantity;    address tokenAddr = receipt.mainchain.tokenAddr;    receipt.info.validate();    if (receipt.kind != Transfer.Kind.Withdrawal) revert ErrInvalidReceiptKind();    if (receipt.mainchain.chainId != block.chainid) {      revert ErrInvalidChainId(msg.sig, receipt.mainchain.chainId, block.chainid);    }    MappedToken memory token = getRoninToken(receipt.mainchain.tokenAddr);    if (!(token.erc == receipt.info.erc && token.tokenAddr == receipt.ronin.tokenAddr && receipt.ronin.chainId == roninChainId)) {      revert ErrInvalidReceipt();    }    if (withdrawalHash[id] != 0) revert ErrQueryForProcessedWithdrawal();    if (!(receipt.info.erc == TokenStandard.ERC721 || !_reachedWithdrawalLimit(tokenAddr, quantity))) {      revert ErrReachedDailyWithdrawalLimit();    }    bytes32 receiptHash = receipt.hash();    bytes32 receiptDigest = Transfer.receiptDigest(_domainSeparator, receiptHash);    uint256 minimumWeight;    (minimumWeight, locked) = _computeMinVoteWeight(receipt.info.erc, tokenAddr, quantity);    {      bool passed;      address signer;      address lastSigner;      Signature memory sig;      uint256 weight;      for (uint256 i; i < signatures.length; i++) {        sig = signatures[i];        signer = ecrecover(receiptDigest, sig.v, sig.r, sig.s);        if (lastSigner >= signer) revert ErrInvalidOrder(msg.sig);        lastSigner = signer;        weight += _getWeight(signer);        if (weight >= minimumWeight) {          passed = true;          break;        }      }      if (!passed) revert ErrQueryForInsufficientVoteWeight();      withdrawalHash[id] = receiptHash;    }    if (locked) {      withdrawalLocked[id] = true;      emit WithdrawalLocked(receiptHash, receipt);      return locked;    }    _recordWithdrawal(tokenAddr, quantity);    receipt.info.handleAssetOut(payable(receipt.mainchain.addr), tokenAddr, wrappedNativeToken);    emit Withdrew(receiptHash, receipt);}

receipt.info.handleAssetOut.merge_dataflows: function _submitWithdrawal(Transfer.Receipt calldata receipt, Signature[] memory signatures) internal virtual returns (bool locked) {uint256 id = receipt.id;uint256 quantity = receipt.info.quantity;address tokenAddr = receipt.mainchain.tokenAddr;receipt.info.validate();if (receipt.kind != Transfer.Kind.Withdrawal) revert ErrInvalidReceiptKind();if (receipt.mainchain.chainId != block.chainid) {revert ErrInvalidChainId(msg.sig, receipt.mainchain.chainId, block.chainid);}MappedToken memory token = getRoninToken(receipt.mainchain.tokenAddr);if (!(token.erc == receipt.info.erc && token.tokenAddr == receipt.ronin.tokenAddr && receipt.ronin.chainId == roninChainId)) {revert ErrInvalidReceipt();}if (withdrawalHash[id] != 0) revert ErrQueryForProcessedWithdrawal();if (!(receipt.info.erc == TokenStandard.ERC721 || !_reachedWithdrawalLimit(tokenAddr, quantity))) {revert ErrReachedDailyWithdrawalLimit();}bytes32 receiptHash = receipt.hash();bytes32 receiptDigest = Transfer.receiptDigest(_domainSeparator, receiptHash);uint256 minimumWeight;(minimumWeight, locked) = _computeMinVoteWeight(receipt.info.erc, tokenAddr, quantity);{bool passed;address signer;address lastSigner;Signature memory sig;uint256 weight;for (uint256 i; i < signatures.length; i++) {sig = signatures[i];signer = ecrecover(receiptDigest, sig.v, sig.r, sig.s);if (lastSigner >= signer) revert ErrInvalidOrder(msg.sig);lastSigner = signer;weight += _getWeight(signer);if (weight >= minimumWeight) {passed = true;break;}}if (!passed) revert ErrQueryForInsufficientVoteWeight();withdrawalHash[id] = receiptHash;}if (locked) {withdrawalLocked[id] = true;emit WithdrawalLocked(receiptHash, receipt);return locked;}_recordWithdrawal(tokenAddr, quantity);receipt.info.handleAssetOut(payable(receipt.mainchain.addr), tokenAddr, wrappedNativeToken);emit Withdrew(receiptHash, receipt);}

The method heavily trusts that the state represented by 'receipt.info' is accurate, which may not always be the case, lowering the overall confidence in the validation's effectiveness.

results.poc: If an attacker can influence the signatures passed in the `signatures` array so they are manipulated, it might allow them to pass the vote weight requirement while having an altered `receipt.info` that does not conform to the expected structure.
results.reason: While the validation checks for the withdrawal condition and signature order are in place, there exists a potential vulnerability if an attacker can manipulate the `signatures` array to bypass these checks. This manipulation may lead to a successful call to `handleAssetOut` with invalid `receipt.info`, as outlined in the PoC. Therefore, the level of confidence is moderately high, but the risk of bypass exists.

Check that the destination chain ID is n.poc: An attacker could create a fake receipt object with receipt.mainchain.chainId set to any value that is not equal to block.chainid. This could be done in scenarios where the smart contract can be called with forged data, allowing the condition check 'if (receipt.mainchain.chainId != block.chainid)' to pass without triggering the revert.
Check that the destination chain ID is n.reason: The validation check for the chain ID comparison can be bypassed by providing a forged receipt object. If malicious entities can craft this receipt with an inaccurate chain ID, they can successfully pass the validation without triggering the revert. However, it's important to evaluate the overall context of the system in which this contract operatesif the function is called in a fully isolated environment with no external manipulation, the risk is reduced. Still, the ability to spoof the receipt indicates a significant vulnerability.

Check that the destination chain ID is n.poc: If the contract has a state variable that can be manipulated or spoofed by another function call before calling _submitWithdrawal, an attacker could potentially alter the effective chainId comparison between receipt.mainchain.chainId and block.chainid, causing the condition to fail.
Check that the destination chain ID is n.reason: The validation that checks if 'receipt.mainchain.chainId' matches 'block.chainid' can potentially be bypassed if an attacker controls a state variable that could influence the outcome of this comparison. This introduces a risk that could lead to unauthorized withdrawals, decreasing the confidence in the security of the check.

Validate that recipientAddress is not th.poc: Bypassing the validation can be achieved by manipulating the 'signatures' array. If signatures are provided in a non-increasing order of their signers, it may bypass the weight check once valid signatures are incorrectly ordered. The function allows for a vote weight check, so if the wrong ordering bypasses enough required weight, it could allow for `handleAssetOut` to be called without proper validation.
Validate that recipientAddress is not th.reason: The function includes some necessary validation checks before calling 'handleAssetOut', like verifying the receipt kind and checking the withdrawal limit. However, the manipulation of the 'signatures' array can potentially allow bypassing the vote weight validation, leading to a risk where 'handleAssetOut' can be invoked with insufficient checks if the signing order is incorrect. This uncertainty in signature handling affects the overall confidence in the validation's effectiveness.

Validate that recipientAddress is not th.poc: An attack vector is to supply a receipt with a manipulated 'chainId' in 'receipt.mainchain.chainId', potentially matching 'block.chainid', while the remaining conditions fail. This could allow for the function to skip the initial chain ID validation, thereby permitting `handleAssetOut` to be executed even with invalid chain parameters.
Validate that recipientAddress is not th.reason: The validation of the chain ID accurately prevents valid transactions but can be bypassed if a malicious actor manipulates the 'chainId' in the receipt. If this manipulated value matches the 'block.chainid', the associated checks can be skipped, allowing `handleAssetOut` to be executed with invalid parameters. This vulnerability introduces a significant risk, hence the score is moderately high, indicating caution is needed in the implementation.

Validate that recipientAddress is not th.poc: If the external function '_reachedWithdrawalLimit' returns false due to manipulated state or external dependency, then `handleAssetOut` could still process a withdrawal with invalid tokens as the required check for limits is bypassed, thus executing the function without following the validation statement correctly.
Validate that recipientAddress is not th.reason: The bypass condition indicates that if '_reachedWithdrawalLimit' returns false, it allows 'handleAssetOut' to be called, thereby bypassing the validation under specific manipulated states. This presents a vulnerability given that external contract interactions can impact internal checks, although proper contract structure mitigates some risks.

For instance, providing a `receipt` that has a valid `handleAssetOut` method but gives a false impression about the balance or asset type can lead to bypassing checks.

result.reason: The ecrecover function can be manipulated by an attacker to produce valid signatures. In cross-chain scenarios, this could allow malicious actors on one chain to impersonate legitimate users on another, potentially leading to unauthorized withdrawals.

The check for processed withdrawals using a simple mapping can be susceptible to replay attacks in cross-chain contexts. An attacker could replay the same transaction from a different chain if proper mechanisms to prevent such actions are not implemented.

Relying on a withdrawal limit check that can be influenced by cross-chain asset validation may expose the contract to economic vulnerabilities, as malicious entities could manipulate the conditions under which asset limits are checked across chains, leading to possible exhaustion of resources.

This validation assumes the integrity of the cross-chain receipt data. If the attacker can submit a forged receipt from a compromised chain, the contract could process invalid withdrawals, resulting in asset loss.

unlockWithdrawal: function unlockWithdrawal(Transfer.Receipt calldata receipt) external onlyRole(WITHDRAWAL_UNLOCKER_ROLE) {

dataflows.reason: The data flow code correctly covers all necessary logic concerning the parameter receipt.id, ensuring it checks against the withdrawalHash and withdrawalLocked states. However, there is a minor oversight in handling scenarios where receipt.id may not be present; thus the correctness score is slightly reduced.

receipt.id.merge_dataflows: function unlockWithdrawal(Transfer.Receipt calldata receipt) external onlyRole(WITHDRAWAL_UNLOCKER_ROLE) {  bytes32 _receiptHash = receipt.hash();  if (withdrawalHash[receipt.id] != receipt.hash()) {    revert ErrInvalidReceipt();  }  if (!withdrawalLocked[receipt.id]) {    revert ErrQueryForApprovedWithdrawal();  }  delete withdrawalLocked[receipt.id];  emit WithdrawalUnlocked(_receiptHash, receipt);  address token = receipt.mainchain.tokenAddr;  if (receipt.info.erc == TokenStandard.ERC20) {    TokenInfo memory feeInfo = receipt.info;    feeInfo.quantity = _computeFeePercentage(receipt.info.quantity, unlockFeePercentages[token]);    TokenInfo memory withdrawInfo = receipt.info;    withdrawInfo.quantity = receipt.info.quantity - feeInfo.quantity;    feeInfo.handleAssetOut(payable(msg.sender), token, wrappedNativeToken);    withdrawInfo.handleAssetOut(payable(receipt.mainchain.addr), token, wrappedNativeToken);  } else {    receipt.info.handleAssetOut(payable(receipt.mainchain.addr), token, wrappedNativeToken);  }  emit Withdrew(_receiptHash, receipt);}

unlockWithdrawal: function unlockWithdrawal(Transfer.Receipt calldata receipt) external onlyRole(WITHDRAWAL_UNLOCKER_ROLE) {

unlockWithdrawal: function unlockWithdrawal(Transfer.Receipt calldata receipt) external onlyRole(WITHDRAWAL_UNLOCKER_ROLE) {

dataflows.reason: The code successfully extracts the usage of 'receipt.mainchain.addr' within the context of handling asset withdrawals. Coverage is complete as all occurrences in the relevant function are present. The correctness score is slightly reduced due to the absence of direct checks for the validity of 'receipt.mainchain.addr', which, while it assumes valid input, is a point of potential failure not explicitly verified.

receipt.mainchain.addr.merge_dataflows: function unlockWithdrawal(Transfer.Receipt calldata receipt) external onlyRole(WITHDRAWAL_UNLOCKER_ROLE) { bytes32 _receiptHash = receipt.hash(); if (withdrawalHash[receipt.id] != receipt.hash()) { revert ErrInvalidReceipt(); } if (!withdrawalLocked[receipt.id]) { revert ErrQueryForApprovedWithdrawal(); } delete withdrawalLocked[receipt.id]; emit WithdrawalUnlocked(_receiptHash, receipt); address token = receipt.mainchain.tokenAddr; if (receipt.info.erc == TokenStandard.ERC20) { TokenInfo memory feeInfo = receipt.info; feeInfo.quantity = _computeFeePercentage(receipt.info.quantity, unlockFeePercentages[token]); TokenInfo memory withdrawInfo = receipt.info; withdrawInfo.quantity = receipt.info.quantity - feeInfo.quantity; feeInfo.handleAssetOut(payable(msg.sender), token, wrappedNativeToken); withdrawInfo.handleAssetOut(payable(receipt.mainchain.addr), token, wrappedNativeToken); } else { receipt.info.handleAssetOut(payable(receipt.mainchain.addr), token, wrappedNativeToken); } emit Withdrew(_receiptHash, receipt); }

result.reason: This line checks if the receipt hash matches an expected hash, but if the validation logic is flawed or if the receipt is incorrectly constructed due to cross-chain inconsistencies, it can lead to unauthorized access or denial of service. Malicious actors may exploit discrepancies in the format of receipts across chains.

This check for the locked state might not adequately protect against re-entrancy attacks, especially in cross-chain scenarios where state divergence can occur. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to exploit race conditions if proper locking mechanisms arent employed.

The handling of asset transfers does not account for possible failures or reverts from external contracts, particularly in cross-chain transfers. If a transfer fails on one chain but passes on another, it can lead to loss of funds or inconsistencies in state, as the contract might erroneously assume the transaction was successful.
